title: Why ASX volunteered for a culture self-assessment
text:
The RBA assessment suggests it is satisfied with ASX’s progress on its risk improvement program to date, noting that as of June 30, KPMG confirmed 28 of the 36 recommendations of its original review had been closed.

While Stevens is quick to emphasise that risk management has always been a strong focus for ASX, given its place in the financial system, the KPMG review and subsequent self-assessment has helped it focus on what he says has been a profound change in expectations around non-financial risks since the royal commission.

Quantifying risks

Much of ASX’s focus has been on improving the way it quantifies risks – boiling them down to objective metrics, rather than subjective opinions – and being very clear on exactly who owns what risks through the business.

There have also been changes to how risk issues bubble up to the board, including getting more staff from lower levels in front of directors, more often. For example, when an audit issue is overdue, it is the person with direct responsibility for that matter who must front the board, rather than the head of audit.

As in many companies, the use of data and better analysis is also crucial. Stevens says Treleaven can now see, in close to real time, the way the risk of a default by a certain party could cascade through the ASX system.

The modernisation of the ASX technology stack that Stevens is overseeing clearly creates implementation risks, but should also result in better controls for the ASX over time.

The occasionally controversial blockchain-based system that ASX is developing to replace its core CHESS system for clearing in the cash equities market is a good example.

Stevens says it will drive big improvements in areas such as reliability, cyber security and recoverability. But as the RBA’s assessment makes clear, the bank will be closely watching its rollout.

The CHESS replacement remains on track; the fourth of seven software “drops” is imminent, with industry-wide testing likely to start in July 2020, ahead of the formal launch by April 2021.

Steven says he’s well aware the bar on risk is being raised. The challenge now for ASX is to embed its new processes and tools such that the organisation builds what he describes as “muscle memory”.
description: Dominic Stevens says three years of heightened focus on risk management are helping underpin the group’s broader push to set the market operator up for the next 20 years.
